data.text:
Shane Garner Obituary and death cause will be discussed in the article. Three men were killed in an Airplane crash in California.

Three men from Georgia, including Captain Eric Tatman from Marietta, First Officer Spencer Geerlings from Newnan, and Systems Specialist Shane Garner from Taylorsville, lost their lives in a plane crash during the U.S.

Navy training exercise off the coast of California on Wednesday. The information was reported by Phoenix Air Group, Inc., a company based in Cartersville.

Phoenix Air Group, Inc. expressed its condolences and support for the families of all three men.

You may be interested in: Tower Hamlets Suma Begum Missing Found Dead: Husband Aminan Rahman Charged With Murder

Who Was Shane Garner? Family Details

Shane Garner was identified as a Systems Specialist and one of the three individuals who died in the plane crash during the U.S. Navy training exercise off the coast of California.

Following the news of the death of three individuals in the plane crash, there was increased interest from the public to know more about each person involved in the tragic incident.

But there has only been limited information out in public; Shane, one of the victimâs family, has not come out and shared any information regarding the incident.

It is common for ordinary people to stay out of media and sources; people have been sharing prayers and condolence to the family of the victims at this challenging time.

Capt. Jim Spitler, sector commander for the USCG in San Diego, said, âOur thoughts are with the family and friends of the missing passengers.â

Shane Garner Obituary And Death: Airplane Crash California Update

During a U.S. Navy training exercise, a Phoenix Air Learjet 36 crashed off the coast, killing three individuals.

The deceased has been identified as Eric Tatman, Spencer Geerlings, and Shane Garner, all employed by Phoenix Air, a Georgia-based private company.

San Clemente Island, where the crash occurred, is owned and managed by the Navy.

The Phoenix Air Learjet 36 was one of two planes participating in the military training exercise.

According to Phoenix Air, the planes were conducting a series of flight profiles to support U.S. Navy fleet preparedness as part of a carefully planned military exercise in a restricted area.

The company also stated that it has been conducting readiness training as a contractor for the Navy and the Department of Defense for over 20 years.

While one jet landed safely, the other crashed into the ocean roughly one-mile southwest of San Clemente Island.

The Coast Guard and Customs and Border Protection crews found Debris in the water.

According to U.S. officials, the Learjet crashed into the Pacific Ocean approximately one mile from a Navy-owned island near San Diego.

The Coast Guard, along with the Navy, Air Force, and Customs and Border Protection, conducted a search operation covering 334 square miles in the surrounding area on Wednesday after the Phoenix Air Learjet crashed in the morning.

Hopefully, the reason behind the death and the crash of the Plane will be disclosed among the public who has been following the news.

The National Transportation Safety Board just confirmed that it is investigating the incident, but so far, there have been no more updates on the investigation.
